column5: Well there are probably about as many different knots as there are fish in the sea but it seems like most people have a favourite knot that they use more than any other. I used to use the improved clinch all the time but after losing a couple of my heavier lures I switched to a palomar knot and use that even when I should probably be using something else.
Palomar knot Pretty much covers things, easy to tie in the dark and when your half blind The other most knot is Snell when tying my hooks.
All I use is the Palomar knot, also been using the double uni to connect two lines but my "go to knot" would be the Palomar!
gone over pretty much to wide gap up eye style hooks and use a snell knot  http://www.steelheader.net/knots/whip_finish.htm   improved clinch elsewhere, but I use low tech mono (ie. cheap ) lines
Duncans Loop is my knot of choice
Palomar for mono, braid and everything else. One of my goals for this season is to learn a few more knots.

8lb(or less) mono or floro to hook, jig or cross lock - Orvis Knot  Adding a a tippet (leader - 8lb or less) - Orvis tippet knot  Polamar for all heavier mono  Uni knot  for braids and joining  a new line to an older backing  muddler
Mono to Leader - Triple Surgeon Mono to Mono - Double Uni / Blood Braid to Mono - Double Uni Light Mono to Hook - Trilene / Palomar / Snell Heavy Mono to Hook - Palomar Braid to Device/Lure - Palomar
I use five knots,depending on application,the improved cinch,,the palomar, double uni, and the repala knot
Rapala knot for pretty much all, unless I am fly fishing
Used to be improved clinch (not for braid though). Now I use the palomar knot most of the time. I can't remember the name of the knot I use for braid, it is recommended by the manufacturer.
So what's the 5th one, Sonny?
Double uni counts as 2.
I was raised to do the single blood knot, and can't shake it.  Old habits die hard I spose.  I'm starting to use the Palomar sometimes, but only with the braided line.  Joey

You should of added a poll to this message before you posted it. lol  I use a Palomar most of the time, but sometimes the improved clinch knot.  Heres a awsome site to check out for those who want to learn those knots plus more. Each knot has a animation and instructions.  Animated Fishing Knots - How To
I used to tie the Trilene all the time and could not complain about it until I switched to the UNI.... that knot is one of the toughest and have confidence in!!! Leechman
Used to rely on the Trilene knot but switched to the Palomar after finding out how easy it is to tie under low light conditions. Uni-to-uni for connecting my mono to braid...  Mike
palomar and clinch knot
Then start here!! Jim http://www.animatedknots.com/usesfishing.p...imatedknots.com
Ohh  sorry roy,,,the snell knot,,,forgot to add that one!

I use to just tie the improved clinch knot as that's what my dad taught me as a kid.  Skip ahead 15 years when I started fishing again and while browsing online I fell in love with the Palomar knot.  It's the strongest I've used and by far the fastest to tie even blindfolded.  I've been using braided line now and use the double uni for braid to flourocarbon or tying to mono backing.
Uniknot.....

Line to hook - Palomar or open loop/rapala knots Line to line - Triple surgeons (Significant difference in diameter) Line to line - Albright special (Similar diameters) Fly line to leader - Nail Knot  Snell and surgeons end loop when tying harnesses etc.  That about sums it up for me.
